[[Spanish language|Spanish]] | website = {{url|http://freenas.org}} }} '''FreeNAS''' is a free [[network-attached storage]] server, supporting: [[CIFS]] ([[Samba (software)|Samba]]), [[File Transfer Protocol|FTP]], [[Network File System (protocol)|NFS]], [[rsync]], [[Apple Filing Protocol|AFP]] protocols, [[internet SCSI|iSCSI]], [[Self-Monitoring, Analysis, and Reporting Technology|S.M.A.R.T.]], local user authentication, and software [[RAID]] (0,1,5), with a web-based configuration interface. FreeNAS takes less than 64 MB once installed on [[CompactFlash]], [[hard drive]] or [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] [[USB flash drive|flash drive]]. FreeNAS is currently distributed as an [[ISO image]] and in [[Source code|source]] form. Through version 7.x, it was possible to run FreeNAS from a [[Live CD]], with the configuration files stored on an MS-DOS-formatted floppy disk or USB thumb drive. There is also a [[VMware]] disk image available (Last updated in 2006)[http://www.vmware.com/appliances/directory/168 FreeNAS on the VMWare Application Marketplace]. With the release of 8.x, Live CD isn't currently supported. FreeNas 8.x needs to be installed on a Compact Flash, USB, or dedicated hard drive. Using the dedicated hard drive will use that drive just for the operating system, and files cannot be stored on it. The minimal [[FreeBSD]] 7.2 distribution, web interface, [[PHP]] scripts, and documentation are based on [[m0n0wall]]. FreeNAS is released under the [[BSD licenses|BSD license]]. It was reported December 2009 that [[FreeBSD]] based development would be halted and put into 'maintenance-only mode' with [[Debian Linux]] as the new development target [[OS]].{{cite web | title = FreeNAS Switching From FreeBSD To Debian Linux | publisher = Slashdot.com | url = http://linux.slashdot.org/story/09/12/06/152205/FreeNAS-Switching-From-FreeBSD-To-Debian-Linux?from=rss&utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Slashdot%2Fslashdot+(Slashdot) | accessdate = 2009-12-07}} This decision was reverted shortly afterwards, when [[iXsystems]] offered to sponsor the further development of FreeNAS.{{cite web | title = FreeNAS ready for the next step ! | publisher = FreeNAS Blog | url = http://blog.freenas.org/2009/12/freenas-ready-for-next-step.html | accessdate = 2009-12-10}}{{cite web | title = Rumours of FreeNAS Death Greatly Exaggerated | publisher = FreeNAS blog | url = http://www.learnfreenas.com/blog/2009/12/05/rumours-of-freenas-death-greatly-exaggerated/ | accessdate = 2009-12-05}} == Features == * Protocols: [[Server Message Block|CIFS]] (via [[Samba (software)|Samba]]), [[Trivial File Transfer Protocol|TFTP]], [[FTP]], [[Network File System (protocol)|NFS]], [[Secure Shell|SSH]], [[rsync]], [[Apple Filing Protocol|AFP]], [[UPnP]], [[BitTorrent (protocol)]] and [[iTunes]]. * Extensions (plug-ins) for: [[SlimServer]], [[XBMC|Xbox Media Stream Protocol]]. * [[rsync]] server, client and local sync. * [[Unison (file synchronizer)|Unison]] support. * [[ISCSI#Targets|iSCSI targets]] feature to create virtual disks. * [[ISCSI#iSCSI_terminology_and_how_iSCSI_can_be_used_by_an_OS|iSCSI initiator]]. * Dynamic DNS client for: [[DynDNS]], [[ZoneEdit]], [[No-Ip]], and [[freedns.afraid.org]]. * File systems: [[ZFS]], [[Unix File System|UFS]] and [[ext2]]/[[ext3]] are fully supported, [[NTFS]] read/write and [[File Allocation Table|FAT32]] read/write supported. * Hard drive: [[Parallel ATA|P-ATA]]/[[Serial ATA|S-ATA]], [[SCSI]], [[iSCSI]], [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] and [[FireWire]]. * [[GUID Partition Table|GPT]]/[[Extensible Firmware Interface|EFI]] partitioning for hard drives larger than 2 Terabytes. * Network cards: All wired and wireless cards supported by [[FreeBSD]] 7.2. * Boot from HDD, USB key, CompactFlash, CD-ROM + floppy disk, or USB flash. * Hardware [[RAID]] cards: All those supported by FreeBSD 7.2. * Software RAID levels: [[RAID0|0]], [[RAID1|1]], [[RAID5|5]], [[JBOD]], [[RAID50|5+0]], 5+1, 0+1, 1+0, etc. (using [[GEOM]] and [[Geom raid5|g_raid5]]). Also [[RAID-Z]] and RAID-Z2 (as part of [[ZFS]]). * 4KB sector formatting support for hard drives using [[Advanced Format|advanced formats]] such as Western Digital WD10EARS, WD15EARS, WD20EARS, and WD30EZRS. * Disk encryption with [[Geli (software)|geli]]. * Management of groups and users (Local User authentication or [[Windows Server domain|Microsoft Domains]]). * [[Self-Monitoring, Analysis, and Reporting Technology|S.M.A.R.T.]] support. * Remote [[syslogd]] forwarding. * [[Simple Network Management Protocol|SNMP]] monitoring (Netgraph and MibII). * Email log and reporting notification. * [[VLAN]] support * [[Link aggregation]] and [[Fail over|link failover]] interface * [[Uninterruptible power supply|UPS (Uninterruptible power supply)]] support * [[Time Machine (Mac OS)|Apple Time Machine]] support == Awards == * VMware - "Ultimate Virtual Appliance Challenge, Consumer"{{cite web | title = FreeNAS is a Network-Attached Storage (NAS) server | publisher = VMware, Inc. | url = http://www.vmware.com/appliances/directory/168 | accessdate = 2008-02-28}} * sourceforge.net - Project of the Month January 2007{{cite web | title = Project of the Month January 2007 | publisher = SourceForge, Inc. | url = http://sourceforge.net/potm/potm-2007-01.php | accessdate = 2008-02-28}} * InfoWorld - Best of open source in storage{{cite web | title = Best of open source in storage - 2007 | publisher = InfoWorld | url = http://www.infoworld.com/slideshow/2007/09/117-best_of_open_so-3.html | accessdate = 2008-02-28}} == See also == * [[Comparison of iSCSI targets]] * [[OpenMediaVault]] - an out-of-the-box Linux NAS solution developed by a former FreeNAS developer, based upon Debian Linux (previous name: CoreNAS) * [[NASLite]] - another low-cost commercial NAS operating system from the developers of NanoNAS * [[Nexenta]] - Open source OS and enterprise class NAS with kernel based ZFS * [[Open-E]] - Unified file and block storage management software that supports NAS, iSCSI, InfiniBand, Fibre Channel, SAN and Failover * [[Openfiler]] * [[Zentyal]] == References == {{refs}} == External links == {{commonscat}} * [http://freenas.org/ FreeNAS Homepage] * [http://blog.patyuen.com/lessons/technology/idiot%E2%80%99s-guide-to-installing-freenas/ Step by step installation guide for FreeNAS] *[http://www.learnfreenas.com/ Learn FreeNAS] * Radio World - Aug 11, 2009 - [http://www.radioworld.com/article/85170 FreeNAS: A Simple Data Storage Solution] * Washington Post/PC World - Aug 27, 2008 [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/26/AR2008082600237.html Network-Attached Storage on the Cheap] * Videotutorial with German Translator Falk at sysops.tv -
